metadata.title: Markup & Margin Calculator
metadata.description: Compute selling price, markup percentage, and gross margin from cost or price. Includes conversions between markup and margin and clear formulas you can audit against accounting and government guidance.

price_from_cost_and_markup.label: Selling price from cost and markup
price_from_cost_and_markup.description: Calculate the required selling price and resulting margin when you enter unit cost and markup percentage.

markup_from_cost_and_price.label: Markup percentage from cost and selling price
markup_from_cost_and_price.description: Find the markup percentage required to move from cost to a target selling price.

margin_from_cost_and_price.label: Gross margin and markup from cost and selling price
margin_from_cost_and_price.description: Calculate both gross margin (as a percent of price) and markup (as a percent of cost) from cost and selling price inputs.

convert_markup_margin.label: Convert between markup and margin
convert_markup_margin.description: Convert a markup percentage to the equivalent gross margin percentage and vice versa.

introduction: This calculator helps you compute selling price, markup percentage, and gross margin from cost or price inputs. It also converts between markup (percent of cost) and margin (percent of selling price) using standard accounting formulas.

Formulas are explicit and reversible: markup = (price - cost) / cost, margin = (price - cost) / price, and conversions use margin = markup / (1 + markup) (expressed as percentages). Use the method that matches the values you know (cost+markup, cost+price, or direct conversion).
methodology: All calculations use basic algebraic definitions used in managerial accounting and pricing practice. Selling price from cost and markup: price = cost × (1 + markup%). Markup from cost and price: markup% = (price − cost) / cost × 100. Margin from cost and price: margin% = (price − cost) / price × 100.

When converting between markup and margin the tool uses exact fractional relationships to avoid approximation errors: margin% = markup% / (100 + markup%) × 100, and markup% = margin% / (100 − margin%) × 100. These forms are algebraically equivalent to decimal formulations used in accounting texts.

Monetary outputs are presented in currency format and percentages are shown to two decimal places by default. For compliance or financial filing, round according to your accounting policy and consult tax guidance for inventory and cost recognition rules.

faqs.question: What is the difference between markup and margin?
faqs.answer: Markup is the percentage added to cost to reach price (profit relative to cost). Margin (gross margin) is profit as a percentage of the selling price. They will always differ unless cost is zero; use markup when setting a price over cost and margin when analysing profitability relative to revenue.

faqs.question: How do I choose which method to use?
faqs.answer: If you know unit cost and want to set a price, use the 'Selling price from cost and markup' method. If you have a target selling price and want to know the markup applied to cost, use 'Markup percentage from cost and selling price'. Use the conversion method when translating target margins into required markup or vice versa.

faqs.question: How should I round results for invoices or catalogs?
faqs.answer: Round monetary values and percentages according to your internal pricing policy and regulatory needs. For everyday pricing, round to the smallest currency unit (e.g., cents). For financial reports follow your accounting standards; when in doubt, align rounding with your ERP/accounting system to avoid reconciliation issues.

faqs.question: Are these calculations compliant with tax and inventory rules?
faqs.answer: The formulas themselves are arithmetic and not tax rules. For tax, cost recognition and inventory valuation follow jurisdictional accounting rules—consult official guidance such as IRS publications or your local tax authority and your accountant for treatments that affect taxable income.

faqs.question: What if I need to include taxes, shipping, or variable overheads?
faqs.answer: This calculator focuses on basic unit-level price, markup, and margin math. To include taxes or additional per-unit costs, add those costs into the 'Unit cost' field before computing markup or selling price so the markup covers all variable costs. For complex overhead allocations, use formal costing methods (e.g., activity-based costing) and reconcile with accounting policies.
